key_insight: AdaTooler-V enables multimodal LLMs to decide when to call vision tools for images and videos, avoiding unnecessary tool invocations to cut inference overhead and improve end-task performance.
problem_solved: Open-source MLLMs often exhibit blind tool-use—invoking vision tools even when not needed—leading to higher latency, compute cost, and degraded performance; this paper solves adaptive, necessity-aware tool invocation for visual tasks.
method: A lightweight decision/gating module that predicts whether a given visual query requires external vision-tool access (images or video frames).
Interleaved multimodal chain-of-thought with conditional tool invocation: the model uses internal multimodal reasoning by default and calls vision tools only when the gate indicates utility.
Cost-aware training/objective that balances task accuracy and tool-usage overhead, evaluated across image and video benchmarks to demonstrate reduced calls and maintained or improved accuracy.
impact: Makes multimodal LLMs more computationally efficient and practically deployable for image/video tasks by reducing unnecessary tool calls, lowering latency and cost while preserving or enhancing task performance.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart showing: input (image/video) → gating decision → (No tool) internal reasoning OR (Yes tool) vision-tool invocation → final answer.
Bar chart comparing average inference time, number of tool calls, and accuracy for AdaTooler-V vs baseline blind-tool models.
Before/after example: a visual question solved without tool vs with tool (annotated screenshots) to illustrate when tool-use is helpful.
Timeline/heatmap for a video task showing selective frame-level tool invocations vs continuous tool usage.
paper_title: AdaTooler-V: Adaptive Tool-Use for Images and Videos
paper_authors: Chaoyang Wang, Kaituo Feng, Dongyang Chen, Zhongyu Wang, Zhixun Li
